Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Modeling and measuring patterns of airflow in sauropsid lungs, with special emphasis on integrating research with education of the blind and on broader impacts.
Award.AbstractNarration: The end of the Permian period is marked by the most severe extinction event in the history of the earth in which approximately 96% of marine species and 70% of terrestrial species died out. A central question in the history of life is how the biosphere recovered from this massive extinction event. A key factor driving the major transitions in terrestrial vertebrates may have been changes in atmospheric oxygen and carbon dioxide. This research will investigate lung form and function relationships, which will provide insight into the question of the competitive advantages gained by the archosaur radiation (a group that includes dinosaurs, pterosaurs, birds, crocodilians, and others). The project will provide training in cardiopulmonary physiology and bioengineering of fluid systems and will integrate science and education, broaden participation of underrepresented groups, and benefit society by training a graduate student and a postdoctoral researcher in how to integrate research and education to become outstanding teacher-scholars. In partnership with the Utah Museum of Natural History and the National Federation for the Blind (NFB), the students will help develop, test, evaluate, and implement enquiry based learning kits that will consist of tactile materials designed to teach the scientific process and fundamental principles of functional morphology and evolutionary biology to blind K-12 students. The research will build infrastructure to serve the blind community both within Utah and throughout our nation; this infrastructure will extend the lifespan of this work beyond the tenure of the grant.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcomes of this award regarding merit review criterion I consist of the following:

(1) Knowledge was generated about structure-function relationships in the lungs of a range of different vertebrates, spanning the scale of organization from a gross anatomical level to a cellular and molecular level. The scientific team discovered the presence of aerodynamic valves in the lungs of a number of different vertebrates and helped reveal the evolutionary history of these pulmonary structures as well as shed light on the underlying fluid dynamic basis for the valves. The team also contributed to work showing that the conventional wisdom of the structure of the blood-gas barrier, the tissues that form the barrier between the gases in the lungs and the blood in the capillaries, is incomplete. While the conventional view has been that there is a single type of endothelial cell that lines the capillaries, in mammals there are two specialized cell types, but this complexity appears to be absent in reptiles. This discovery brings up many new questions about the function and evolutionary history of this cellular and molecular diversity.

(2) The use of virtual reality was pioneered in the development of computational fluid dynamics models of pulmonary airflow. This included the development of software and methodologies to generate faithful mathematical representations of complex anatomical shapes that were subsequently used for the computational models. Although originally developed for research purposes, these advances are being applied to teaching anatomy.

(3) Members of the next generation of scientists in STEM received training over a range of career stages, from high-school students, to undergraduates, graduates, and postdoctoral scholars. These trainees included women, which are underrepresented in STEM in Utah, as well as students from other underrepresented groups.

(4) The results of the research were communicated to the scientific community through publications in peer-reviewed journals, through book chapters, and through presentations at both national and international scientific meetings.

(5) The results of the research were communicated to the lay community through publications in lay journals and newspapers, the development of websites, in radio interviews, and in working with film crews on nature documentaries, such as the BBC and National Geographic. 

The outcomes of the award with regards to criterion II include the development of tool kits that introduce the science of morphology to visually impaired k-12 students, and the development of innovative and engaging software to teach the science of anatomy in a virtual world using virtual reality. This latter effort turned out to be prescient in developing tools for teaching science remotely and more safely during the COVID-19 pandemic.
